title: The Music Lesson
locations: Barnes Foundation (Philadelphia), Collection Gallery, Room 19, North Wall
description: The scene, a living room with a large open French window through which a garden is visible, is one of domestic activity. In the left foreground, a man with dark hair and a moustache, dressed in a grey suit, and wearing a striped tie, sits in a chair reading a book and smoking a cigarette. On the right a young woman with light brown hair, wearing an elegant white blouse and a black neckband, helps a young boy at a piano; both are absorbed in their task. Only the head and shoulders of the woman and the head of the boy are visible behind the sheet music and the stand of the Pleyel piano which is before them in the foreground. A green publication (a music score) with the name of the composer Haydn on the front and a violin and bow in an open violin case rest on top of the bright pink lid of the piano in the foreground.  Both the right arm and legs of the man in the chair and the end of the piano are cropped by the bottom edges of the canvas. On the wall behind the two figures at the piano is the corner of a picture with a yellow frame on which is depicted a woman with a blue skirt and black top sitting on a tall stool; her head and part of the canvas are cut off by the right edge and top of the canvas. A French window with a light blue frame is open to reveal the garden outside. Just below the window along the wall inside the room is a white radiator. Beyond the ornamental grill of the window in the garden, a woman, in profile, sits in a rocking chair, bent over her sewing. Behind her, in the following order, is a grey path, a small pool, a statue of a nude woman with water cascading into the pool, and a zone of lush green foliage.

medium: Tempera and gold with brown ink underdrawing on parchment
locations: Barnes Foundation (Philadelphia), Collection Gallery, Room 16, East Wall

title: The Nursemaid
locations: Barnes Foundation (Philadelphia), Collection Gallery, Room 03, South Wall
description: Three figures stand by the waterside. The figure on the left stands with his back turned toward the viewer and is wearing a green piece of clothing, possibly a bathing suit. title: The Red Sofa (Le CanapÃ© rouge)
locations: Barnes Foundation (Philadelphia), Collection Gallery, Room 06, East Wall
description: A woman reclines on a red sofa in a bedroom. She props her head on her hand and rests on a violet pillow. She wears a blue dress with flounces, white leggings and white boots. The floor is pink-red with a diamond-shaped pattern. Behind the sofa on the left side is a strip of wallpaper whose pattern is sketchily rendered. To the right of this strip is a large horizontal red folding screen with a floral pattern. In the right corner of the room is a black chair with a yellow seat and the corner of a wardrobe.

title: The Resurrection
displayDate: probably second half of the 15th century
locations: Barnes Foundation (Philadelphia), Collection Gallery, Room 16, North Wall
description: Christ, wearing a red cape, stands in the center next to an open tomb. Three guards surround him and an angel stands behind him. A large castle is in the background.

title: The Resurrection of Christ
locations: Barnes Foundation (Philadelphia), Collection Gallery, Room 04, North Wall
description: A rectangular plaque showing the Resurrection of Christ. Two figures look on in amazement, and another sleeps. The plaque is counter enameled on the reverse.

title: The Sea Seen from Collioure (La Mer vue de Collioure)
locations: Barnes Foundation (Philadelphia), Collection Gallery, Room 10, East Wall
description: The scene is a view of the harbor of Collioure and the coast from the surrounding hills. In the right foreground is a tree whose branches form a canopy over the grass in the immediate foreground. The landscape descends to the village through alternating pink and green zones (possibly vineyards) scattered with olive trees. In the harbor below the pink roofs of houses and the grey steeple of the church in the village are visible. The sea joins the skyline in the distance beyond the village.

title: The Venetian Blinds (Les Persiennes)
locations: Barnes Foundation (Philadelphia), Collection Gallery, Room 23, North Wall
description: A model sits in a chair in a room in front of an open French window. The blue shutters are closed except for an individual panel on the right that is partially open, allowing light to enter the room. On either side of the window are heavy white curtains. The model wears red Oriental culottes and a white shirt. Her long hair, pushed to one side, trails across her right shoulder. Next to her on the right is an armchair over which has been thrown a yellow, blue and pink striped fabric.

title: The Virgin Mary and Saints Peter, Paul, John the Evangelist, and Catherine of Alexandria Appearing to Saint Martin
locations: Barnes Foundation (Philadelphia), Collection Gallery, Room 14, North Wall
description: Three women and two men, all of whom bear haloes, stand before a man seated at a table. The woman who stands farthest to the right holds a wooden wheel with spikes in one hand and a palm(?) in the other. The woman in the foreground, who is wearing a blue robe, holds her hands out toward the seated man. The seated man is wearing a blue robe and holds his left hand up toward the people in front of him. A book lays open on the table in front of him; a scroll, a pen, and an ink jar are also on the table.

title: Three Sisters and "The Rose Marble Table" (Les Trois sÅ“urs Ã  "La Table de marbre rose")
locations: Barnes Foundation (Philadelphia), Collection Gallery, Room 19, West Wall
description: A group of three larger-than-life size female figures are depicted in an interior, one sits in a yellow chair seen from the back on the left while the two others stand behind her and to her right. The seated woman wears a ruffled, white blouse with transparent sleeves, and turns to face the spectator, leaning her right elbow on the back of the chair. The second woman stands behind the seated figure, only the top of her green dress and white collar are visible. The third woman stands on the right, wearing an elegant violet and black top, a black skirt, and a pair of grey boots. Behind them on the wall hangs a painting of a pink table with a sprig of green leaves at its base.

title: Three Sisters with Grey Background (Les Trois sÅ“urs sur fond gris)
locations: Barnes Foundation (Philadelphia), Collection Gallery, Room 19, West Wall
description: A group of three larger-than-life size female figures dressed in Oriental costume are depicted in an interior. Two figures are seated on straight-back chairs in the foreground. The figure on the left, who appears younger than the other two figures, wears a purple North African or Turkish dress, her hair is tied back, and she rests her hands on her knees. The figure on her right, her hair pulled up, wears a green robe and holds a half-folded fan in her left hand. Behind them stand a third woman wearing a yellow oriental dress and a white turban on her head.

title: Three Sisters with an African Sculpture (Les Trois sÅ“urs Ã  la sculpture africaine)
locations: Barnes Foundation (Philadelphia), Collection Gallery, Room 19, West Wall
description: A group of three larger-than-life size female figures are depicted in an interior. On the left, a woman, viewed from the back, wears an exotic green and yellow robe. A second younger woman stands to her right and slightly behind her, dressed in a purple North African or Turkish dress. A third figure sits to her right on a pink patterned armchair reading a book. She wears a white turban, a white dress with black stockings and black shoes tied with bows. In the foreground to her right, stands a Moroccan table with a white plate or tray on which rests a glass, a lemon and a spoon. In the room in the background a Sudanese sculpture rests on the mantle of a fireplace and two pictures hang on the adjacent wall.

title: Triptych
people: Master of the San Quirico Crucifix
medium: Tempera and gold leaf on panel
locations: Barnes Foundation (Philadelphia), Collection Gallery, Room 03, East Wall
description: A triptych with a central image of the crucifix. Christ hangs on the cross with an apostle, the Virgin, St. John the Evangelist, a knight saint, and Sts. Francis and Margaret at the foot of the cross. Blood spurts from Christ's side. In the left panel is a Madonna and Child with two deacon saints. The right panel is divided into two sections: the top section shows the Christ Child with St. Christopher and the bottom section shows Sts. Dominic and Anthony Abbot. There is gold background on all three panels.

title: Two Women Reclining (Deux femmes Ã©tendues)
locations: Barnes Foundation (Philadelphia), Collection Gallery, Room 10, East Wall
description: Two women rest on the green grass of a clearing surrounded by trees. A brown-haired figure on the left lies on the grass with her arms crossed behind her head. She wears a light-colored skirt and a salmon belted blouse with black short sleeves. To her right, a light-haired figure also lies on the grass; she rests on her right side and faces the viewer. She wears a light colored dress with a blue collar and lies on a black blanket of some sort, probably a shawl. On the grass to her right is a blue parasol with black trim. Both women are placed in the foreground, while behind them the grass slopes slightly upwards toward the tree trunks and red and green foliage that rings the clearing; a path curves around the clearing on the right.

title: Vase
locations: Barnes Foundation (Philadelphia), Collection Gallery, Room 09, West Wall
description: This wheel-thrown vessel is heavy. The vase has a flat bottom with four raised, encircling, molded lines around the foot. The body has a gentle swell into a narrow neck and a flared rim. Four raised molded lines encircle the neck. The decoration of sprigs of leaves are applied. The leaves are enough alike to have been made from molds. The leaves are covered with white slip and daubed with green (copper oxide), and their veins are delineated with incised lines (sgraffito) through the slip, exposing the brownish-red body of the clay. The glaze is clear over a slip wash.

title: Vase

locations: Barnes Foundation (Philadelphia), Collection Gallery, Room 13, North Wall
description: A vase with a rolled foot and an out-turned rim, with a band of peaches around the shoulder, blue lines on the interior of the rim and pink lines on the exterior of the neck.

medium: Oil pastel and black crayon on brown wove paper
locations: Barnes Foundation (Philadelphia), Collection Gallery, Room 17, South Wall
description: A park with figures and trees
copyright: Rights held by Katherine Degn, Kraushaar Gallery.See Glackens constituent record for contact information
bibliography1: The Barnes Foundation Journal of the Art Department 2, no. 2 (Autumn 1971): pl. 38.

title: Water Jar
locations: Barnes Foundation (Philadelphia), Collection Gallery, Lower Level, Cabinet 3 Shelf 2, Middle
description: A Zuni polychrome water jar made of red clay with shard tempering that resembles Hopi work. The jar has kaolin white slip with a red underbelly and a sharp underbody/lower flexure. The decoration consists of tadpoles, a knife wing bird, toads, dragonflies, etc.

title: Water Jar
locations: Barnes Foundation (Philadelphia), Collection Gallery, Lower Level, Cabinet 2 Shelf 2, Middle
description: An Acoma polychrome water jar with a rounded body and minor body flexures between the neck and the underbody. The jar has a white clay body, black exterior rim, red interior rim, red base and underbody, and no secondary banding. The decoration consists of two zonal fields--one surrounds the neck with six serially repeated design units and the other primary field, which surrounds the mid-body and upper under body with six similar units diagonally subdivided.

title: Water Jar
locations: Barnes Foundation (Philadelphia), Collection Gallery, Lower Level, Cabinet 2 Shelf 3, Middle
description: An Acoma black-on-white water jar with a black rim, red inner lip, and red/orange under body. The decoration consists of three tied horizontal bands with serial repetition of linear geometric designs.

title: Water Jar
locations: Barnes Foundation (Philadelphia), Collection Gallery, Lower Level, Cabinet 2 Shelf 3, Right
description: A Zia polychrome water jar made of red clay with black basalt temper. The jar has a high stone polish of white body slip and black and red designs. The underbody has highly polished secondary red banding. The jar is highly decorated with unusual decoration of the inner lip and polished white slip with zig-zag black design extending from the black rim. A black painted checkerboard with white negative squares surrounds the exterior neck. A major line break extends from the rim through three stacked neck design bands ending in a downward pendant surround repeated in three panels. In the additional three panels, a Cochiti pyramid and downward extending rain symbols are emphasized. On the other side of a rainbow, two upright Keresan bird feathers are shown with diagonally extending lightening strikes.

title: Water Jar
locations: Barnes Foundation (Philadelphia), Collection Gallery, Lower Level, Cabinet 2 Shelf 3, Left
description: A Zia polychrome water jar with a flaring upper body shoulder, a tapered up-thrust neck, and a sharply tapered keel shaped underbody. The jar has a black rim and a red-slipped underbody with a polished secondary separating band. The decoration consists of a three-fold design with polychrome birds separated by a grid of intersecting red arches or rainbows, which house the birds.

title: Water Jar
locations: Barnes Foundation (Philadelphia), Collection Gallery, Lower Level, Cabinet 1 Shelf 2, Middle
description: A Zuni polychrome water jar made of red clay with shard tempering that resembles Hopi work. The jar has kaolin white slip with a red underbelly and a sharp underbody/lower flexure. The decoration consists of tadpoles, a knife wing bird, toads, dragonflies, etc.
bibliography1: Pick, Marcelle. "Life is a Journey for Which We Need More Than 'Bon Voyage.'" Vistas 3, no. 2 (1987-1988): 11 ill.

title: Water Jar
locations: Barnes Foundation (Philadelphia), Collection Gallery, Lower Level, Cabinet 4 Shelf 1, Left
description: A Santa Ana polychrome water jar with a more squat, round body form than the earlier San Pablo barrow form. The base is compacted and round and the neck is a truncated extension of the shoulder. The jar has a red/buff clay body with basalt temper, a black rim, and an unslipped stone polished underbody with a secondary polished red band. There is a two zone design field--one around the neck defined by a pendant black band with a line break and the lower zonal edge with a thick red upper design band of mid-body decoration. The symmetrical design is made up of four pendant modified "C" shaped step pyramids in serial repetition both with and without black framing lines.

title: Water Jar
locations: Barnes Foundation (Philadelphia), Collection Gallery, Lower Level, Cabinet 4 Shelf 1, Middle
description: A Santo Domingo black-on-cream water jar made of buff clay with quartz and basalt temper. The jar has a red-slipped underbody with a secondary polished red banding strip. The main body has white kaolin slip with a black rim. The jar has an exaggerated vase shape with an out-flaring neck and rim. There is one main zonal design field in which four design units, each matched in pairs of two, are placed on a negative background. Two birds with "D" shaped bodies are interspersed with two "U" shaped fleurs-de-lis.

title: Water Jar
locations: Barnes Foundation (Philadelphia), Collection Gallery, Lower Level, Cabinet 4 Shelf 1, Right
description: A Zia polychrome water jar made of red brick clay with basalt temper. The jar has a slipped underbody-base with a secondary polished red band and a black rim. The decoration consists of one primary zonal field of design extending from the neck to the underbody junction. Six design units are separated in composition--two diamonds contain flower-stars and four units are concentric ellipses.

title: Water Jar
locations: Barnes Foundation (Philadelphia), Collection Gallery, Lower Level, Cabinet 4 Shelf 2, Left
description: A Zia polychrome water jar with a rounded, old traditional Zia vase form. The jar has a red clay body with basalt temper and a red-slipped highly polished underbody-base. The decoration is composed of one serially-repeated design field in which the zone is subdivided into three units that contain birds surrounded by geometric forms and floral sprays.

title: Water Jar
locations: Barnes Foundation (Philadelphia), Collection Gallery, Lower Level, Cabinet 4 Shelf 2, Middle
description: A Zuni/Kiapkwa polychrome water jar made of buff clay with temper and with a black rim and red-brown base. The vessel has an elongated, barrow shape with two-thirds of the form in the mid-body, a truncated and up-thrust neck, and sharply flexured and tapered underbody. A two-zone design field dominates the vessel--one around the neck featuring three modified prayer feather designs and a major zone around the body consisting of five serial repetitions of a step fret maze with fine cross-hatching.
bibliography1: Dolkart, Judith F., Martha Lucy, and Derek Gillman. The Barnes Foundation: Masterworks. New York: Skira Rizzoli, 2012: 345.

title: Water Jar
locations: Barnes Foundation (Philadelphia), Collection Gallery, Lower Level, Cabinet 5 Shelf 2, Right
description: A Zia four-color polychrome water jar made of red brick clay with basalt temper. It is vase-shaped with a high mid-body shoulder and tapered underbody. A red band frames the black rim and a secondary polished red band surrounds the underbody. One primary zone of decoration extends from the neck to the junction of the underbody with the mid-body and includes polychrome flower sprays with the serial repetition of birds--either chickens or quail.

title: Water Jar
locations: Barnes Foundation (Philadelphia), Collection Gallery, Lower Level, Cabinet 4 Shelf 3, Left
description: A Zuni polychrome water jar made of white-gray clay with a black core. The jar has a rounded neck and underbody junction flexure. Two zonal design fields surround the pot. The neck band has four panels in which two modified prayer feather motifs are symmetrically balanced and composed. The body zone is divided into four panels with rain birds and a rosette with prayer feathers.

title: Water Jar
locations: Barnes Foundation (Philadelphia), Collection Gallery, Lower Level, Cabinet 4 Shelf 4, Right
description: A Zuni black-on-cream water jar with medicine jar designs and a strong mid-body flexure between upper body, neck, and underbody base. There is white, crazed slip on the body, with a brown-black rim and underbody base. The jar has a white-gray clay body with black core. The decoration consists of two zonal design fields, one around the neck with serial repetition of tadpoles, and the second around the mid-body with four toads interspersed with four bird-dragonflies.

title: Water Jar
locations: Barnes Foundation (Philadelphia), Collection Gallery, Lower Level, Cabinet 4 Shelf 4, Left
description: A squat Zuni polychrome water jar made of white clay with a dark core. The two-zone field design includes neck band geometrics and mid-body deer in houses. Two Spanish-derived rosettes make up the remainder of the design.

title: Water Jar
locations: Barnes Foundation (Philadelphia), Collection Gallery, Lower Level, Cabinet 5 Shelf 1, Left
description: A Santa Ana polychrome water jar made of red/buff clay with basalt temper. The jar has a high mid-body design separation, broad lower mid-body polished red banding above an unslipped underbody, heavy red and black paint, and a black rim. There are two zonal bands of tiered decoration including a classic "C" shaped motif with a three-fingered fringe and an interior step pyramid. The red interior motifs are both black outlined and unoutlined.
bibliography1: Dolkart, Judith F., Martha Lucy, and Derek Gillman. The Barnes Foundation: Masterworks. New York: Skira Rizzoli, 2012: 345.

title: Water Jar
locations: Barnes Foundation (Philadelphia), Collection Gallery, Lower Level, Cabinet 5 Shelf 1, Middle
description: A Santo Domingo black-on-white water jar made of pink clay with stone temper. The jar has white rag-wiped slip with black decorations and a polished secondary red band surrounding the base. The decoration consists of two horizontally-banded design fields with serial repetition of linear designs. The use of black triangular motifs to create negative semi-circles and crescents is typical of Santo Domingo vessels.

title: Water Jar
locations: Barnes Foundation (Philadelphia), Collection Gallery, Lower Level, Cabinet 5 Shelf 1, Right
description: A Zia polychrome water jar made of red clay with black basalt temper. The red underbody is polished with a secondary highly polished darker red band. The jar has tan body slip and a black rim. The decoration consists of a four-fold design divided by an undulating double-banded rainbow. The painted band creates semi-spiral negative design fields within which heart-shaped forms are contained.

title: Water Jar
locations: Barnes Foundation (Philadelphia), Collection Gallery, Lower Level, Cabinet 5 Shelf 2, Left
description: A Zia four-color polychrome water jar made of red clay with black basalt temper. The jar has an orange-red underbody, a secondary polished red band, and a black rim. The decoration consists of a four panels of symmetrical birds and floral motifs delineated by undulating two-color rainbows.

title: Water Jar
locations: Barnes Foundation (Philadelphia), Collection Gallery, Lower Level, Cabinet 5 Shelf 2, Middle
description: A Zuni black-on-cream water jar with medicine jar designs and a strong mid-body flexure with upper body, neck, and underbody base. There is white, crazed slip on the body, with a brown-black rim and underbody base. The jar has a white-gray clay body with black core. The decoration consists of zonal design fields, one around the neck with serial repetition of tadpoles and around around the mid-body with four toads interspersed with bird-dragonflies.

title: Water Jar
locations: Barnes Foundation (Philadelphia), Collection Gallery, Lower Level, Cabinet 4 Shelf 2, Right
description: A Zia polychrome water jar with a high rounded shoulder, a short truncated neck, and a sharp tapered underbody. The jar has a black rim and a red clay body with black basalt temper. A secondary polished red band encircles the red-slipped underbody. The three-fold design layout includes a symmetrical balance of three birds separated by three flower sprays.

title: Water Jar
locations: Barnes Foundation (Philadelphia), Collection Gallery, Lower Level, Cabinet 5 Shelf 3, Right
description: A Santo Domingo black-on-cream water jar made of buff clay with red sandstone and crystalline temper. The jar has a black out-flaring rim, polished red underbody slip, and crazed stone polished white body slip. The decoration consists of two zonal design fields stacked upon one another. The upper body field is dominated by an undulating composition of black sunflowers connected by leafy vines, a Spanish derived floral motif. The lower body is demarcated by two line separators, which use characteristic triangles in bifold rotational symmetry to create negative arches.

title: Water Jar
locations: Barnes Foundation (Philadelphia), Collection Gallery, Lower Level, Cabinet 5 Shelf 3, Left
description: A Santo Domingo black-on-cream water jar made of buff clay with temper. The vessel has an exaggerated shape, black rim, and a red polished underbody. The diagnostic Domingo zonal layout of two bands horizontally built upon one another is evident. The design features the classic use of triangles to create negative trapezoids and rhomboids.

title: Water Jar
locations: Barnes Foundation (Philadelphia), Collection Gallery, Lower Level, Cabinet 5 Shelf 4, Right
description: An Acoma polychrome water jar made of white clay with red sherd temper. The jar has an extended out-flaring shoulder, a small up-thrust neck, black rim, and red base. The decoration consists of three ovoids, which are internally subdivided by a central horizontal band and serially repeated Zuni-style birds contained within upper and lower deer houses. The ovoids are separated from one another by a vertical band of step pyramids and a central checkerboard diamond.

title: Water Jar
locations: Barnes Foundation (Philadelphia), Collection Gallery, Lower Level, Cabinet 5 Shelf 4, Left
description: An Acoma polychrome water jar with a rounded body and short neck with self flexure characteristic of the period. The decoration consists of a tri-fold design separated by zigzags. Modified Zuni rain birds are seen in spirals capped by stepped pyramids.

title: Water Jar
locations: Barnes Foundation (Philadelphia), Collection Gallery, Lower Level, Cabinet 6 Shelf 4, Left
description: An Acoma/Laguna polychrome water jar with a rounded olla form and a squat truncated neck rounding into the mid-body. The rim is black and the underbody base has no secondary banding. The interior of the rim is red-slipped. Two zonal fields surround the pot--one at the neck and the other around the mid-body. The neck field is subdivided into five units by vertical zigzag units separating five serially repeated yellow/red hourglasses. The main body features three design units defined by diagonal zigzag steps. The primary designs are three polychrome rosettes with star-flowers in the center and a bifold rotation of rain birds on either side.

title: Water Jar
locations: Barnes Foundation (Philadelphia), Collection Gallery, Lower Level, Cabinet 6 Shelf 4, Right
description: An Acoma four-color polychrome water jar made of white clay with quartz temper. The vessel has a sharply tapered vase shape, a black rim, a red base, and white body slip. One main design field extends around the vessel body. Four serially repeated parrots perch on fruiting branches and have bodies that are alternately colored red and yellow.

title: Water Jar
locations: Barnes Foundation (Philadelphia), Collection Gallery, Lower Level, Cabinet 6 Shelf 3, Right
description: An Acoma black-on-cream water jar made of white-gray clay with no dark core. The vessel has a sharp, outflaring shoulder, concave flexure to the neck, and sharp taper to the underbody. The paint is dark brown/black with a black underbody and a black rim. The decoration is a precise modification of Zuni rain birds circles. The delicate cross-hatching of the interior motifs is also characteristic of Zuni pottery. Three zonal body design fields encircle the vessel--one at the neck, one at the mid-body, and one at the underbody. The serial repetition of designs is reversed in each succeeding zone to create a sense of movement and spin.

title: Water Jar
locations: Barnes Foundation (Philadelphia), Collection Gallery, Lower Level, Cabinet 6 Shelf 2, Right
description: A Zuni polychrome water jar made of gray-white clay with a dark core. There is sharp flexure at the junction of the neck to the mid-body and the mid-body to the underbody. The vessel has a black rim and base and white body slip. Two zones of repeated designs surround the body. The top zone, at the neck, is divided into five serial design panels dominated by a curvilinear rain bird design. The mid- to lower body design repeats three step-fret cross-hatched patterns.

title: Water Jar
locations: Barnes Foundation (Philadelphia), Collection Gallery, Lower Level, Cabinet 6 Shelf 2, Middle
description: A Zia polychrome water jar made of red brick clay and black basalt temper. The jar has a secondary stone polished red band.

title: Water Jar
locations: Barnes Foundation (Philadelphia), Collection Gallery, Lower Level, Cabinet 6 Shelf 2, Left
description: A Zuni polychrome water jar made of white-gray clay with a black core. The jar has a black rim and base, shaped neck, upper body flexure, and minor underbody flexure. The decoration consists of a three-fold, six-panel design with symmetrical patterns interspersed in zonal serial repetition. Two zones surround the pot--one at the neck and the second at the mid-body.

title: Water Jar
locations: Barnes Foundation (Philadelphia), Collection Gallery, Lower Level, Cabinet 6 Shelf 1, Right
description: A Zuni polychrome water jar made of gray-white paste clay with a black core. A sharp ridged flexure delineates the tapered upper neck from the bulbous mid-body, as is the case with the separation of the mid-body from the underbody. The piece has a black rim and underbody. Two zonal design fields--one encircling the neck and one the shoulder and mid-body--are subdivided into four units, in which two units each are symmetrical. The neck shows deer in houses made up of a triangular internally cross-hatched prayer feathers or plumes. The body shows the elaborate Spanish-derived conchos or rosettes and deer in houses separated by Spanish-derived birds.

title: Water Jar
locations: Barnes Foundation (Philadelphia), Collection Gallery, Lower Level, Cabinet 6 Shelf 1, Middle
description: A Zia polychrome water jar made of red brick clay body with basalt temper. The jar has a red base with a secondary polished red band. A continuous zonal field of design surrounds the jar from the neck to the underbody and is divided into four units defined by an undulating red double ribbon rainbow band. This band creates an above and below register within which birds are housed. The birds are characteristic Zia birds with an ear topknot.

title: Water Jar
locations: Barnes Foundation (Philadelphia), Collection Gallery, Lower Level, Cabinet 6 Shelf 1, Left
description: A Zia polychrome water jar with an elongated body form, rounded upper shoulder high on the vessel, and a short neck with a scalloped rim. The jar has a red clay body with black basalt temper. The body design is a continuous zonal serial repetition of a Spanish-influenced tile grid made up of valley stars.

title: Water Jar
locations: Barnes Foundation (Philadelphia), Collection Gallery, Room 15, North Wall
description: A Santa Anna polychrome water jar made of buff clay with basalt temper. The jar has a black rim and a heavy polished red slip band on the underbody above an unslipped base. There are two zonal fields of design. The one around the neck has a serial repetition of negative arches and red "V" and "U" shapes. The other around the main body is subdivided into four panels with red step pyramids serially repeated using a 180-degree bifold rotation of each succeeding unit.

medium: Tin over sheet iron and iron
locations: Barnes Foundation (Philadelphia), Collection Gallery, Room 10, SE Corner

title: Woman Reclining

She wears an oriental costume, which consists of baggy red trousers and a white shawl that covers her head and breasts like a hijab. Behind the sofa on the left, is a French window with a curtain. On the right, the area behind the sofa is covered with two different decorative patterns; the first has brown arabesques on a pink background and the second has a green, floral arrangement on a brown-yellow background.

title: Woman and Screen (La Femme au paravent)
medium: Oil on canvas (later mounted to cardboard and fiberboard)
locations: Barnes Foundation (Philadelphia), Collection Gallery, Room 19, East Wall
description: A woman with brown hair is seated at a table in a green wooden chair in a room. She wears a white blouse and a lavender jacket and her left elbow rests on the arm of the chair. To her right is the corner of a brown table. Behind her on the right, three panels of a folding screen are visible; each panel has a different pattern: blue, pink and blue flowers on a white ground, and a bluish pattern of vertical stripes and dots. In the back on the left, the room is sketchily rendered, though a brown door is visible on the far left and a green area is directly behind her head.

title: Woman on a Red Sofa (Femme sur un canapÃ© rouge)
locations: Barnes Foundation (Philadelphia), Collection Gallery, Room 18, North Wall
description: A woman rests on a red sofa in a bedroom, holding a book on her knees. Her feet as well as the bottom of the sofa are cropped by the bottom edge of the canvas. She wears a striped robe and her hair is pulled up by a comb ornamented with pink roses and green leaves. The carpet has a black and yellow interlace pattern on a red ground. Behind the sofa are a chair, a bed, a dressing table, and a closed door. An oval mirror, a round vase and a second vase with a bouquet, sit on top of the dressing table. The wall in the background is covered with a white and yellow wallpaper.

title: Young Girl on a Balcony over the Ocean (Jeune fille au balcon sur la mer)
medium: Oil on canvas (later mounted to fiberboard)
locations: Barnes Foundation (Philadelphia), Collection Gallery, Room 19, North Wall
description: A woman sits in a tan chair on a balcony overlooking the sea on a bright, sunny day.  The woman, whose body and the chair are turned to the side in three-quarter profile, looks directly at the viewer, her back to the sea. Her hands are folded in her lap. She wears a black outfit with long sleeves, a white v-neck collar, white shoes with bows and white stockings. She has short brown hair that peaks out from under a fashionable beige hat. The balcony has white railings that cast diagonal shadows onto the balcony floor, implying that the sun is low and behind her. The boardwalk and the blue sea are visible through the bars of the balcony behind and below the woman.

title: Young Woman before an Aquarium (Jeune fille devant un aquarium)
displayDate: between the end of September 1921 and February 1922
locations: Barnes Foundation (Philadelphia), Collection Gallery, Room 23, North Wall
description: A woman sits in a chair at a table in a room. She rests her chin on her arms, which are folded in front of her, and stares into a bowl with three goldfish. Pine branches and pine cones are arranged on the wooden table in front of her. Behind her on the right is the edge of a fireplace. To the left of the fireplace are five drawings hung on a decorated green wallpaper. On the far left, is an Islamic red fabric with a floral pattern on a brown wall.
